text.p: - Slovenian Prime Minister-designate Janez Drnovsek will meet Janez Jansa, head of the centre-right Social Democrats, and Lojze Peterle of the Christian Democrats on Wednesday in an effort to form a broad coalition.
- Slovenia's parliament has managed to form only some less important working bodies since November's general election.

- Slovenia's only refiner Nafta said it will lose 130 million tolars ($902,777) each month because the government refuses to raise petrol prices. Nafta has demanded a 10 percent increase in petrol prices.
- Despite some financial problems Slovenia still insists on its candidature to host the 2006 winter Olympics together with neighbouring Austria and Italy.
- Almost 600,000 people visited Ljubljana fair in 1996, the event's general manager said.

- Ciril Pucko, a Christian Democrat who defected before a parliamentary vote to give Janez Drnovsek a vital 46th vote that helped in his election as prime minister-designate received at least five threatening letters after he changed his phone number, police reported.
- On Tuesday police caught one of Slovenia's major drug dealers, the 35 year-old owner of a popular pub in Ljubljana.
- Slovenia's scientists on Tuesday demanded the immediate resignation of Minister of Science and Technology Andrej Umek because of inappropriate science policy.
- Some 386 km (235 miles) of new motorways are expected to be constructed by the end of 1999, the country's motorway construction company said.
